papers.title: Detection of four cold Jupiters through combined analyses of radial velocity and astrometry data
papers.abstract: Cold Jupiters play a crucial role in planet formation and dynamical evolution. Since their initial discovery around 47 UMa, they have attracted significant interest, yet their formation mechanisms remain uncertain, underscoring the need to expand the known population. In this work, we combine RV data with Gaia astrometry using Hipparcos-Gaia proper-motion anomalies over a 25-year baseline. By jointly modeling both datasets with the MCMC framework, we constrain planetary masses, orbital inclinations, and three-dimensional orbital architectures. This reduces RV degeneracies and improves mass determinations. Four cold Jupiters are reported: HD 68475 b and HD 100508 b are each the first confirmed planet in their systems, with orbital periods 7832 (+463/-323) d and 5681¬±42 d and dynamical masses of 5.16 (+0.53/-0.47) M_(Jup) and 1.2 (+0.30/-0.18) M_(Jup), respectively. In multi-planet systems, HD 48265 c has a period of 10418 (+2400/-1400) d and a mass of 3.71 (+0.68/-0.43) M_(Jup), while HD 114386 c orbits at 444.00 (+0.93/-0.88) d with a minimum mass of 0.37 ¬± 0.03 M_(Jup). The two planets in the HD 48265 system may exhibit a significant mutual inclination, making it a target for testing the von-Zeipel-Kozai-Lidov mechanism. HD 68475 b is a promising candidate for future direct imaging with ELT/METIS. We identified a Jupiter analog with the longest known orbital period among planets with masses between 0.5 and 2 M_(Jup), implying that a substantial population of cold Jupiters likely awaits discovery by Gaia. This study expands the sample of cold Jupiters with constrained orbits and dynamical masses, demonstrating the value of combining radial velocity and astrometry in exoplanet research.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine if we could only see the shadow of a person walking by a streetlight, never the person themselves. That's essentially how astronomers have been finding planets around other stars‚Äîdetecting their subtle effects rather than seeing them directly. This research represents a major step forward in our ability to understand distant worlds, particularly "cold Jupiters"‚Äîgiant planets that orbit far from their host stars, much like our own Jupiter. These distant giants are crucial pieces in the cosmic puzzle of how planetary systems form and evolve, yet we've found surprisingly few of them. Understanding why could reshape our knowledge of how common solar systems like ours really are.

**What They Did**

The researchers combined two different planet-hunting techniques to get a more complete picture of these distant worlds. First, they used the "wobble method," which detects how a planet's gravity causes its host star to move slightly back and forth. Second, they analyzed precise measurements of star positions from the European Space Agency's Gaia spacecraft, which can detect the tiny shifts in a star's position caused by an orbiting planet. By combining data spanning 25 years and using sophisticated computer modeling, they could determine not just that planets exist, but also their actual masses and the shapes of their orbits‚Äîinformation that's usually difficult or impossible to obtain.

**Key Findings**

The team discovered four new cold Jupiter planets orbiting distant stars. Two of these worlds are the first planets ever confirmed in their respective systems. The most impressive find is a Jupiter-like planet that takes over 21 years to complete one orbit‚Äîthe longest orbital period ever found for a planet in this mass range. These planets range from about one-third the mass of Jupiter to over five times Jupiter's mass, showing the diversity of giant worlds that exist beyond our solar system.

**Looking Forward**

This research demonstrates that many more cold Jupiters are likely waiting to be discovered as our technology improves. Some of these newly found worlds may even be candidates for direct imaging with next-generation telescopes, potentially allowing us to study their atmospheres and compositions directly‚Äîa major leap toward understanding planetary formation throughout the galaxy.

papers.title: Aligned, Misaligned and Polar Orbits of Hot Jupiters: Measuring Spin-Orbit Angles via Doppler Tomography with HARPS-N
papers.abstract: Although the migration of hot Jupiters is not yet fully understood, measurements of the projected spin-orbit angle Œª help shed light on the processes involved. Here we present Doppler tomography of three known hot Jupiters to determine their Œª orientation: HAT-P-49 b, HAT-P-57A b, and XO-3A b. Our analysis explores the impact of cross-correlation processing methods on the detectability and characterization of the planet's Doppler shadow using up to three independent routines for cross-correlation functions extraction; those being: Yabi, iSpec and IRAF. After accounting for differences among the results obtained with the various routines, we report: first, the HAT-P-49 system is a case of a hot Jupiter on a polar orbit with Œª=-85.3¬±1.7¬∞, second, HAT-P-57A indicates practically no deviation of the planet's projected orbit from the host's equatorial plane with Œª=-0.4 (+1.4/-1.9)¬∞, and third, the XO-3A system with the measured value of Œª=38+3_(-4)¬∞ lies in between an aligned and a perpendicular orientation, which is a less populated region of the spin-orbit distribution. Our findings highlight both the diversity of spin-orbit angles among close-in giant planets and the potential discrepancies in their measurement that can arise from different approaches to constructing the cross-correlation functions.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine spinning a basketball on your finger while a marble orbits around it. Now picture that marble's orbit tilted at a crazy angle‚Äîmaybe even going over the poles instead of around the equator. This bizarre scenario actually happens with some of the most extreme planets we've discovered: hot Jupiters. These are gas giant planets that orbit incredibly close to their stars, completing a full year in just days. By measuring how tilted these planetary orbits are compared to their star's rotation, astronomers can piece together the violent history of how these worlds ended up in such extreme locations. It's like being a cosmic detective, using clues from today to understand dramatic events that happened billions of years ago.

**What They Did**

The researchers used a technique called Doppler tomography to study three hot Jupiter systems. Think of it like taking an X-ray of starlight. When a planet crosses in front of its star, it blocks light from different parts of the star's surface as it moves. Since stars rotate, different parts move toward or away from us at different speeds, slightly changing the color of their light. By carefully analyzing these tiny color changes during planetary transits, scientists can map how the planet's orbit is oriented relative to the star's spin. The team used three different computer programs to analyze their data, ensuring their results were reliable and not dependent on any single method.

**Key Findings**

The three planets showed dramatically different orbital orientations. HAT-P-49 b orbits over its star's poles‚Äîimagine the marble going from north pole to south pole instead of around the equator. HAT-P-57A b follows a perfectly normal equatorial orbit, like planets in our solar system. Most intriguingly, XO-3A b sits at a 38-degree tilt, occupying a middle ground that few hot Jupiters inhabit. This is like finding a planet that's neither perfectly aligned nor completely sideways‚Äîa rare configuration that challenges our understanding of planetary migration.

**Looking Forward**

These findings add crucial pieces to the puzzle of hot Jupiter formation. The diversity of orientations suggests multiple pathways brought these planets so close to their stars‚Äîsome migrated gently through their birth disks, others were violently scattered by gravitational interactions. Understanding these processes helps astronomers predict what kinds of planetary systems exist throughout our galaxy.

papers.title: KMT-2025-BLG-1616Lb: First Microlensing Bound Planet From DREAMS
papers.abstract: We present observations and analysis of the bound planetary microlensing event KMT-2025-BLG-1616. The planetary signal was captured by the Korea Microlensing Telescope Network (KMTNet) and the DECam Rogue Earths and Mars Survey (DREAMS). DREAMS's minute-cadence observations break the central/resonant degeneracy in the binary-lens models. The color of the faint source star (I=22) is measured from the DREAMS's r - z color. The planetary system has a planet-host mass ratio of q ~ 5 √ó 10^(-4). A Bayesian analysis yields a host-star mass of ~ 0.3\,M_‚òâ, a planetary mass of ~ 40\,M_(‚äï), a projected planet-host separation of ~ 1.6~au, and a lens distance of ~ 7.5~kpc. Based on the photometric precision achieved by DREAMS for this event, we simulate free-floating planet (FFP) detections and find that DREAMS is sensitive to Mars-mass FFPs in the Galactic bulge and Moon-mass FFPs in the Galactic disk.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to spot a firefly buzzing around a lighthouse from thousands of miles away‚Äîthat's essentially what astronomers face when hunting for planets orbiting distant stars. Most exoplanet detection methods only work for massive planets orbiting close to their stars, leaving smaller, more distant worlds largely invisible. This research demonstrates a powerful technique called microlensing that can find these elusive planets, including ones that might be similar to Earth or Mars. Understanding what types of planets exist throughout our galaxy helps us piece together how planetary systems form and whether Earth-like worlds are common or rare.

**What They Did**

The team used a cosmic magnifying glass effect called gravitational microlensing. When a star passes directly in front of another star from our perspective, its gravity bends light like a lens, temporarily brightening the background star. If the foreground star has a planet, it creates a distinctive blip in this brightening pattern‚Äîlike a signature that reveals the planet's presence. Two telescope networks worked together: the Korea Microlensing Telescope Network spotted the initial signal, while the DECam Rogue Earths and Mars Survey (DREAMS) took ultra-frequent observations‚Äîone measurement per minute‚Äîto capture crucial details that resolved ambiguities in the data.

**Key Findings**

The researchers discovered a Neptune-sized planet roughly 40 times more massive than Earth, orbiting a small red dwarf star about one-third the mass of our Sun. The planet sits approximately 1.6 times farther from its star than Earth does from the Sun, and the entire system lies about 7,500 light-years away toward the center of our galaxy. This marks the first planet discovery for the DREAMS survey, proving the technique works exceptionally well for finding smaller worlds.

**Looking Forward**

This success suggests DREAMS could detect free-floating planets‚Äîworlds ejected from their star systems and wandering alone through space. The survey appears sensitive enough to spot Mars-sized wanderers and possibly even Moon-sized objects, opening an entirely new window into planetary populations across our galaxy.

papers.title: The impact of disc photoevaporation on the long-term evolution of giant planets in mean motion resonances
papers.abstract: We investigate the long-term impact of disc photoevaporation on the dynamical stability and evolution of giant planet pairs in mean motion resonances. Using two-dimensional hydrodynamical simulations with FARGO3D, in which we have included mass-loss due to photoevaporation, we explore a parameter space covering disc mass, viscosity, planet mass, and resonance type. We find that strong photoevaporation depletes gas in the common gap between the planets, slowing migration and suppressing planet-disc interactions that typically lead to resonance breaking and eccentricity damping. This stabilising effect is most significant for 3:2 resonances, which are more prone to disruption due to the reduced planet spacing. In contrast, 2:1 resonances are generally more robust but can still be destabilised at high disc mass and moderate-to-strong photoevaporation due to asymmetric torques. Photoevaporation can therefore stabilise resonances that would otherwise break, or conversely disrupt resonances that are natively more stable. Even in cases where photoevaporation does not directly affect resonance stability, it typically results in increased planetary eccentricities. These results highlight the complex, system-dependent nature of resonance evolution, with implications for the final orbital architectures of giant planet systems and their detectability via astrometry from missions such as Gaia.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine two massive planets locked in a cosmic dance, orbiting their star in perfect synchronization‚Äîone completes exactly two orbits for every three of its neighbor, like clockwork that's been running for millions of years. These "resonant" relationships are surprisingly common among the thousands of exoplanets we've discovered, but scientists have struggled to understand how they form and why some survive while others fall apart. This research tackles a crucial missing piece of the puzzle: how intense stellar radiation that strips away the gas disk around young stars affects these delicate planetary partnerships. Understanding this process helps us decode the life stories of planetary systems and explains why we see such diverse arrangements of worlds beyond our solar system.

**What They Did**

The researchers created detailed computer simulations to watch planetary systems evolve over millions of years. They modeled young star systems where two giant planets (similar to Jupiter) orbit in lockstep while embedded in a disk of gas and dust. In their virtual laboratory, they cranked up the intensity of a process called photoevaporation‚Äîwhere the star's intense radiation essentially boils away the surrounding gas disk. They tested different scenarios by varying the disk's mass, how thick or thin the gas was, the planets' weights, and how tightly synchronized the planetary orbits were. Think of it like running multiple experiments to see how different cooking temperatures and ingredient amounts affect the final recipe.

**Key Findings**

The results revealed a surprising twist: intense stellar radiation can actually stabilize some planetary partnerships that would otherwise break apart. When radiation strips gas from the space between planets, it reduces the gravitational forces that normally push planets out of sync. This stabilizing effect works best for planets in 3:2 resonances (three orbits to two), which are naturally more fragile. However, the process can backfire for planets in 2:1 resonances (two orbits to one), sometimes destabilizing these normally robust relationships. In all cases, the planets end up with more stretched, oval-shaped orbits rather than circular ones.

**Looking Forward**

These discoveries help explain the incredible diversity of planetary systems we observe today. The research suggests that a star's radiation environment during a system's youth plays a crucial role in sculpting the final arrangement of planets. This has practical implications for upcoming space missions like the European Space Agency's Gaia telescope, which will measure tiny stellar wobbles caused by orbiting planets. By understanding how these resonant relationships evolve, astronomers can better predict which types of planetary systems to look for and refine their detection strategies, bringing us closer to finding Earth-like worlds in stable, long-lasting orbits.

papers.title: Metal Pipe: A Broadly-Applicable Stellar Abundance Pipeline Using Isochronal Parameters
papers.abstract: Characterizing exoplanet host stars at a population level requires a method of homogeneously characterizing stellar properties across all spectral types. To this end, we have developed Metal Pipe, a new code for determining stellar parameters and abundances, which is designed for use across a wider range of spectral types than many commonly used codes. It combines the widely-used package MOOG with photometric stellar parameters, a user-supplied high-resolution spectrum, and a newly curated list of spectral lines. Metal Pipe outputs values for T_(eff), (g), M_*, R_*, and L_* from isochrones, and abundances of C, O, Na, Mg, Al, Si, S, Ca, Ti, and Fe from MOOG. In this paper, we describe the Metal Pipe algorithm and tests of Metal Pipe against previous abundance measurements on archival HIRES spectra of 503 F, G, and K type stars. We find RMS scatters of ~100 K in T_(eff), ~0.10 dex in (g), and ~0.10 dex for all measured abundances. These values are comparable to estimated measurement uncertainties, verifying Metal Pipe for continued use in building a detailed abundance catalog. Future papers in this series will test Metal Pipe's applicability to late K and M dwarf stars, and provide other improvements.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to understand different neighborhoods by studying the houses in them‚Äîbut each house was analyzed by a different inspector using different methods. That's the challenge astronomers face when studying stars that host planets outside our solar system. With thousands of exoplanets discovered, scientists need a consistent way to analyze their host stars across the galaxy. Understanding what these stars are made of helps us learn how planetary systems form and whether they might harbor worlds similar to Earth. This research tackles that challenge by creating a universal tool for analyzing stellar chemistry.

**What They Did**

Researchers developed a new computer program called "Metal Pipe" that works like a standardized recipe for analyzing stars. The program takes high-quality light measurements from telescopes‚Äîessentially stellar fingerprints that reveal what elements are inside each star‚Äîand processes them using consistent methods. Think of it as creating a universal translator that can read the chemical signatures of different types of stars, from those slightly smaller than our Sun to those much larger. The team tested their new tool on 503 previously studied stars to make sure it produced reliable results compared to earlier measurements.

**Key Findings**

The new tool successfully measured ten different chemical elements in stars, including carbon, oxygen, iron, and others that are crucial for planet formation. When compared to previous measurements, Metal Pipe's results were remarkably consistent‚Äîtemperature measurements differed by only about 100 degrees Kelvin (roughly equivalent to the difference between a warm day and a hot day), while chemical abundance measurements were accurate to within 10% margins. This level of precision means astronomers can now confidently compare stars across large populations.

**Looking Forward**

This standardized approach will help astronomers build comprehensive catalogs of exoplanet host stars, potentially revealing patterns about which types of stars are most likely to form Earth-like planets. As the tool gets refined for smaller, cooler stars, it could unlock insights about the most common planetary systems in our galaxy.
